column2: Thoughtful, very disturbed, dissatisfied with himself, and resolved to turn his back upon the dreary life of pleasure which for so long a time had allowed him no rest, and now disgusted him, he kept aloof from his travelling companions, and rejoiced when, at Alexandria, he was led ashore in the harbour of Eunostus.
column3: Thoughtful, very disturbed, dissatisfied with himself, and resolved to turn his back upon the dreary life of pleasure which for so long a time had allowed him no rest, and now disgusted him, he kept aloof from his travelling companions, and rejoiced when, at Alexandria, he was led ashore in the harbour of Eunostus.

column2: CHAPTER VII.

column2: Hermon entered his house with drooping head.
column3: Hermon entered his house with drooping head.

column2: Here he was informed that the grammateus of the Dionysian artists had already called twice to speak to him concerning an important matter. When he came from the bath, Proclus visited him again.

column2: His errand was to invite him to a banquet which was to take place that evening at his residence in a wing of the royal palace.
column3: His errand was to invite him to a banquet which was to take place that evening at his residence in a wing of the royal palace.

column2: But Hermon was not in the mood to share a joyous revel, and he frankly said so, although immediately after his return he had accepted the invitation to the festival which the whole fellowship of artists would give the following day in honour of the seventieth birthday of the old sculptor Euphranor.

column3: The grammateus alluded to this, and most positively insisted that he could not release him; for he came not only by his own wish, but in obedience to the command of Queen Arsinoe, who desired to tell the creator of the Demeter how highly she esteemed his work and his art.

column2: She would appear herself at dessert, and the banquet must therefore begin at an unusually early hour.
column3: She would appear herself at dessert, and the banquet must therefore begin at an unusually early hour.

column2: He, Proclus, was to have the high honour of including the royal lady among his guests solely on Hermon's account, and his refusal would be an insult to the Queen.
column3: He, Proclus, was to have the high honour of including the royal lady among his guests solely on Hermon's account, and his refusal would be an insult to the Queen.

column2: So the artist found himself obliged to relinquish his opposition.
column3: So the artist found himself obliged to relinquish his opposition.

column2: He did this reluctantly; but the Queen's attention to him and his art flattered his vanity and, if he was to abandon the intoxicating and barren life of pleasure, it could scarcely be done more worthily than at a festival where the King's consort intended to distinguish him in person.

column2: The banquet was to begin in a few hours, yet he could not let the day pass without seeing Daphne and telling her the words of the oracle.
column3: The banquet was to begin in a few hours, yet he could not let the day pass without seeing Daphne and telling her the words of the oracle.

column2: He longed, with ardent yearning, for the sound of her voice, and still more to unburden his sorely troubled soul to her.
column3: He longed, with ardent yearning, for the sound of her voice, and still more to unburden his sorely troubled soul to her.

column2: Oh, if only his Myrtilus still walked among the living!
column3: Oh, if only his Myrtilus still walked among the living!

column2: How totally different, in spite of his lost vision, would his life have been!
column3: How totally different, in spite of his lost vision, would his life have been!

column2: Daphne was now the only one whom he could put in his place.
column3: Daphne was now the only one whom he could put in his place.

column2: Since his return from the oracle, the fear that the rescued Demeter might yet be the work of Myrtilus had again mastered him.
column3: Since his return from the oracle, the fear that the rescued Demeter might yet be the work of Myrtilus had again mastered him.

column2: However loudly outward circumstances might oppose this, he now felt, with a certainty which surprised him, that this work was not his own.
column3: However loudly outward circumstances might oppose this, he now felt, with a certainty which surprised him, that this work was not his own.

column2: The approval, as well as the doubts, which it aroused in others strengthened his opinion, although even now he could not succeed in bringing it into harmony with the facts.
column3: The approval, as well as the doubts, which it aroused in others strengthened his opinion, although even now he could not succeed in bringing it into harmony with the facts.

column2: How deep had been the intoxication in which he had so long reeled from one day to the next, since it had succeeded in keeping every doubt of the authorship of this work far from him!
column3: How deep had been the intoxication in which he had so long reeled from one day to the next, since it had succeeded in keeping every doubt of the authorship of this work far from him!

column2: Now he must obtain certainty, and Daphne could help him to it; for, as a priestess of Demeter, she possessed the right to procure him access to the cella and get permission for him to climb the lofty pedestal and feel the statue with his fingers, whose sense of touch had become much keener.

column2: It would have been a grave crime to woo her before he was relieved of this uncertainty, and he would utter the decisive words that very day, and ask her whether her love was great enough to share the joys and sorrows of life with him, the blind man, who perhaps must also divest himself of a false fame.
column3: It would have been a grave crime to woo her before he was relieved of this uncertainty, and he would utter the decisive words that very day, and ask her whether her love was great enough to share the joys and sorrows of life with him, the blind man, who perhaps must also divest himself of a false fame.

column2: Time pressed.

column2: He called at Archias's house with a wreath on his head and in festal robes; but Daphne was in the temple, whither old Philippus and Thyone had gone, and his uncle was attending a late session of the Council.

column2: He would have liked to follow Daphne to the sanctuary, but the late hour forbade it, and he therefore only charged Gras to tell his young mistress that he was going to Proclus's banquet, and would return early the next morning to discuss a most important subject with her.

column2: Then he went directly to the neighbouring palace.
column3: Then he went directly to the neighbouring palace.

column2: The Queen might have appeared already, and it would not do to keep her waiting.
column3: The Queen might have appeared already, and it would not do to keep her waiting.

column2: He was aware that she lived at variance with her husband, but how could he have suspected that she cherished the more than bold design of hurling the sovereign from his throne and seizing the Egyptian crown herself.

column2: Proclus and Althea were among the conspirators who supported Arsinoe, and the Queen thought it would be an easy matter to win over to her cause and herself the handsome sculptor, whom she remembered at the last Dionysia.

column2: The wealthy blind artist, so highly esteemed among the members of his profession, might become valuable to the conspiracy, for she knew what enthusiastic devotion the Alexandrian artists felt for the King, and everything depended upon forming a party in her own favour among them. column2: When returning home from a banquet, if his way lay through the city, he was reminded of the superb buildings, marble terraces and fountains, statues and porticoes, which had formerly satiated his eyes with delight, and must now be illumined with a brilliant radiance by the morning sunbeams, though a hostile fate shut them out from his eyes, starving and thirsting for beautiful forms.

column2: But it had seemed to him still harder to bear that his blinded eyes refused to show him the most beautiful of all beautiful things, the human form, when he lingered among the Ephebi or the spectators of a festal procession, or visited the gymnasium, the theatre, the Aphrodisium, or the Paneum gardens, where the beautiful women met at sunset.

column2: The noble lady, whispered Althea, "needs the faithful devotion of every well-disposed subject, for perhaps you have already learned how cruelly the King embitters the life of the mother of his three children. Many a caprice can be forgiven the suffering Ptolemy, who recently expressed a wish that he could change places with the common workmen whom he saw eating their meal with a good appetite, and who is now tortured by the gout; yet he watches the hapless woman with the jealousy of a tiger, though he himself is openly faithless to her.

column2: Only, even though love has wholly disappeared, she still claims consideration, and Althea did not wish to lose Hermon's regard.
column3: Only, even though love has wholly disappeared, she still claims consideration, and Althea did not wish to lose Hermon's regard.

column2: When Amyntas, the head of the conspirators, attracted the attention of the company by malicious remarks about the King's sister, the Thracian laid her hand on the blind artist's arm, whispering: "Has the image of the Arachne which, at Tennis, charmed you even in the presence of the angry Zeus, completely vanished from your memory?
column3: When Amyntas, the head of the conspirators, attracted the attention of the company by malicious remarks about the King's sister, the Thracian laid her hand on the blind artist's arm, whispering: "Has the image of the Arachne which, at Tennis, charmed you even in the presence of the angry Zeus, completely vanished from your memory?

column2: How indifferent you look!
column3: How indifferent you look!

column2: But I tell you"--her deep blue eyes flashed as she spoke--"that so long as you were still a genuine creating artist the case was different. Even while putting the last touches of the file to the Demeter, for which Archias's devout daughter posed as your model, another whom you could not banish from your mind filled your imagination.
column3: But I tell you"--her deep blue eyes flashed as she spoke-"that so long as you were still a genuine creating artist the case was different. Even while putting the last touches of the file to the Demeter, for which Archias's devout daughter posed as your model, another whom you could not banish from your mind filled your imagination.

column2: Though so loud a denial is written on your face, I persist in my conviction, and that no idle delusion ensnares me I can prove!"
column3: Though so loud a denial is written on your face, I persist in my conviction, and that no idle delusion ensnares me I can prove!"

column2: Hermon raised his sightless eyes to her inquiringly, but she went on with eager positiveness: "Or, if you did not think of the weaver while carving the goddess, how did you happen to engrave a spider on the ribbon twined around the ears of grain in Demeter's hand?
column3: Hermon raised his sightless eyes to her inquiringly, but she went on with eager positiveness: "Or, if you did not think of the weaver while carving the goddess, how did you happen to engrave a spider on the ribbon twined around the ears of grain in Demeter's hand?

column2: Not the smallest detail of a work produced by the hand of a valued friend escapes my notice, and I perceived it before the Demeter came to the temple and the lofty pedestal.
column3: Not the smallest detail of a work produced by the hand of a valued friend escapes my notice, and I perceived it before the Demeter came to the temple and the lofty pedestal.

column2: Now I would scarcely be able to discover it in the dusky cella, yet at that time I took pleasure in the sight of the ugly insect, not only because it is cleverly done, but because it reminded me of something"--here she lowered her voice still more--"that pleased me, though probably it would seem less flattering to the daughter of Archias, who perhaps is better suited to act as guide to the blind.
column3: Now I would scarcely be able to discover it in the dusky cella, yet at that time I took pleasure in the sight of the ugly insect, not only because it is cleverly done, but because it reminded me of something"--here she lowered her voice still more-"that pleased me, though probably it would seem less flattering to the daughter of Archias, who perhaps is better suited to act as guide to the blind.

column2: How bewildered you look!
column3: How bewildered you look!

column2: Eternal gods!
column3: Eternal gods!

column2: Many things are forgotten after long months have passed, but it will be easy for me to sharpen your memory.
column3: Many things are forgotten after long months have passed, but it will be easy for me to sharpen your memory.

column2: 'At the time Hermon had just finished the Demeter,' the spider called to me, 'he scratched me on the gold.' But at that very time--yes, my handsome friend, I can reckon accurately--you had met me, Althea, in Tennis, I had brought the spider-woman before your eyes.
column3: 'At the time Hermon had just finished the Demeter,' the spider called to me, 'he scratched me on the gold.' But at that very time-yes, my handsome friend, I can reckon accurately-you had met me, Althea, in Tennis, I had brought the spider woman before your eyes.

column2: Was it really nothing but foolish vanity that led me to the conviction that you were thinking of me also when you engraved on the ribbon the despised spider-for which, however, I always felt a certain regard--with the delicate web beneath its slender legs?"
column3: Was it really nothing but foolish vanity that led me to the conviction that you were thinking of me also when you engraved on the ribbon the despised spider for which, however, I always felt a certain regard-with the delicate web beneath its slender legs?"

column2: Hitherto Hermon had listened to every word in silence, labouring for breath.
column3: Hitherto Hermon had listened to every word in silence, labouring for breath.

column2: He was transported as if by magic to the hour of his return from Pelusium; he saw himself enter Myrtilus's studio and watch his friend scratch something, he did not know what, upon the ribbon which fastened the bunch of golden grain.
column3: He was transported as if by magic to the hour of his return from Pelusium; he saw himself enter Myrtilus's studio and watch his friend scratch something, he did not know what, upon the ribbon which fastened the bunch of golden grain.

column2: It was--nay, it could have been nothing else--that very spider.
column3: It was-nay, it could have been nothing else-that very spider.

column2: The honoured work was not his, but his dead friend's.
column3: The honoured work was not his, but his dead friend's.

column2: How the exchange had occurred he could not now understand, but to disbelieve that it had taken place would have been madness or self-deception.
column3: How the exchange had occurred he could not now understand, but to disbelieve that it had taken place would have been madness or self deception.

column2: Now he also understood the doubts of Soteles and the King.
column3: Now he also understood the doubts of Soteles and the King.

column2: Not he--Myrtilus, and he alone, was the creator of the much-lauded Demeter!
column3: Not he-Myrtilus, and he alone, was the creator of the much lauded Demeter!

column2: This conviction raised a hundred-pound weight from his soul.
column3: This conviction raised a hundred pound weight from his soul.

column2: What was applause!
column3: What was applause!

column2: What was recognition!
column3: What was recognition!

column2: What were fame and laurel wreaths!
column3: What were fame and laurel wreaths!

column2: He desired clearness and truth for himself and all the world and, as if frantic, he suddenly sprang from his cushions, shouting to the startled guests: "I myself and this whole great city were deceived! The Demeter is not mine, not the work of Hermon!
column3: He desired clearness and truth for himself and all the world and, as if frantic, he suddenly sprang from his cushions, shouting to the startled guests: "I myself and this whole great city were deceived! The Demeter is not mine, not the work of Hermon!

column2: The dead Myrtilus created it!"
column3: The dead Myrtilus created it!"

column2: Then pressing his hand to his brow, he called his student friend to his side, and, as the scholar anxiously laid his arm on his shoulder, whispered: "Away, away from here!
column3: Then pressing his hand to his brow, he called his student friend to his side, and, as the scholar anxiously laid his arm on his shoulder, whispered: "Away, away from here!

column2: Only let me get out of doors into the open air!"
column3: Only let me get out of doors into the open air!"

column2: Crates, bewildered and prepared for the worst, obeyed his wish; but Althea and the other guests left behind felt more and more impressed by the suddenly awakened conviction that the hapless blind man had now also become the victim of madness.
column3: Crates, bewildered and prepared for the worst, obeyed his wish; but Althea and the other guests left behind felt more and more impressed by the suddenly awakened conviction that the hapless blind man had now also become the victim of madness.

column2: CHAPTER VIII.
column3: CHAPTER eight.

column2: Without a word of explanation, Hermon dragged his guide along in breathless haste.
column3: Without a word of explanation, Hermon dragged his guide along in breathless haste.

column2: No one stopped them.
column3: No one stopped them.

column2: The atrium, usually swarming with guards, servants, and officials until a far later hour, was completely deserted when the blind man hurried through it with his friend.
column3: The atrium, usually swarming with guards, servants, and officials until a far later hour, was completely deserted when the blind man hurried through it with his friend.

column2: The door leading into the outer air stood open, but Hermon, leaning on the scholar's arm, had scarcely crossed the threshold and entered the little courtyard encircled with ornamental plants, which separated this portion of the palace from the street, when both were surrounded by a band of armed Macedonian soldiers, whose commander exclaimed: "In the name of the King!
column3: The door leading into the outer air stood open, but Hermon, leaning on the scholar's arm, had scarcely crossed the threshold and entered the little courtyard encircled with ornamental plants, which separated this portion of the palace from the street, when both were surrounded by a band of armed Macedonian soldiers, whose commander exclaimed: "In the name of the King!

column2: Not a sound, if you value your lives!"
column3: Not a sound, if you value your lives!"
